titleStmt.title: A machine-readable profile of Aden Arabic
titleStmt.author: Aleksandra Ercegovčević

sourceDesc.p: This is an original digital text

div.head: Typology (Local)
div.p: Urban dialect with many phonological peculiarities

div.head: General
div.p: Aden is the most important port in Yemen with a long history and a population of approximately 800,000 people. Its harbor is formed by two volcanic peninsulas – Aden (Ǧabal šamsām) and Little Aden (ǧabal insān) – which are connected with the mainland to the north by short necks of sand.

Before British administration (1839-1967) Aden was ruled respectively by the Portuguese and the Ottoman Empire. As a colony under British rule, it was an important transit port and coaling station for trade between Europe and British India and the Far East. The commercial and strategic importance of Aden increased considerably when the Suez Canal opened in 1869. From then until the 1960s, the Port of Aden was one of the busiest ship-bunkering, duty-free shopping, and trading ports in the world. The city was the capital of the People's Democratic Republic of Yemen until that country's unification with the Yemen Arab Republic in 1990.

div.head: Research history
div.p: The first studies on the dialect of Aden date back to the middle of the 20th century. Emerson/Ghanem 1943 is a grammar of the dialect of Aden. Dawod 1952 is a comprehensive study on the phonetics and phonology of the dialect of the 'Port of Aden' or, more accurately, of the part of the port known as "The Crater". Palatography, kymography, and radiography were utilized in this study; thus its appendices include tongue positions and cross-sectional views of the face upon the realisation of different sounds. Ghanem 1958 is a textbook of Aden Arabic and at the same time an essential source for its morphological and syntactical structures.

Feghali 1990 is a collection of 45 texts, each followed by a list of the most important vocabulary plus linguistic notes, with English translation in the second part of the monograph. Al Yaari et al. 2012 is a concise article treating vowel deletion in various Yemeni dialects, including that of Aden.

div.head: Dictionaries
div.p: Stace 1893 is an English-Arabic dictionary of the dialect of Aden. Ghanem 1958 includes an Arabic-English/English-Arabic glossary.

div.head: Text books
div.p: Ghanem 1958 is an 18-lesson textbook of Aden Arabic. Each lesson includes a dialogue, notes on grammar and idioms, a grammar chapter, a vocabulary list, and exercises.
